An algebraic form, or simply form, is a function defined by a homogeneous polynomial.[2] A binary form is a form in two variables. A form is also a function defined on a vector space, which may be expressed as a homogeneous function of the coordinates over any basis. A polynomial of degree 0 is always homogeneous; it is simply an element of the field or ring of the coefficients, usually called a constant or a scalar. A form of degree 1 is a linear form.[3] A form of degree 2 is a quadratic form. In geometry, the Euclidean distance is the square root of a quadratic form. Homogeneous polynomials are ubiquitous in mathematics and physics.[4] They play a fundamental role in algebraic geometry, as a projective algebraic variety is defined as the set of the common zeros of a set of homogeneous polynomials.
